posts.name: Foster
posts.cooked: Help me with the right term. Crown gears have teeth sticking up like little points from the face, whereas spur gears have teeth on the outer edge. In the image shown, the white gear is the one I'm asking about, with blue gears on the spur part and a green gear riding on the crown gear points. So, what is the correct name for this combination?

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: VEX in Delmarva - Chief Roboteer STEMRobotics

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: Crown gear, cage gear, or lantern gear are all similarly overlapping terms for that type of gear.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
A crown gear and a spur gear with the same tooth pitch share this arrangement. Crown gears typically feature a face width along with a crown profile rather than just points. Here, a crown is placed on top, and a spur is on the side, both aligned orthogonally with the same pitch.  

This setup is notable for being closely packed together.  

As an aside, I’m not familiar with VEX, but it seems like this could be a differential swerve module using crown gears, as seen here: [971 differential swerve](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/pic-differential-swerve-module-971/160525).  

For a humorous touch, names like clown gear or jaw gear could work as playful alternatives.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: The Gear s-l400 is a crown gear, commonly referred to as such due to its appearance.

posts.name: Foster
posts.cooked: I would characterize this as a crown gear and a spur gear that share a tooth pitch (allowing for this beautiful packaging). Good way to describe it, thanks. Still looking for a shorter name that they are called.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: VEX in Delmarva - Chief Roboteer STEMRobotics

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: This is about the best Crown and Pinion spur bevel gearbox I can come up with. It serves as a gearbox designed to describe both types of gears required; the bevel aspect indicates where they intersect at a 90-degree angle, similar to other beveled spur gears.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: These sorts of gears are really nice for toys because they can act as bevel gears, spur gears, or both simultaneously. However, they wouldn’t typically be used in applications requiring significant load or efficiency. For optimal performance, normal spur gear teeth and miter gear teeth are needed. While it’s possible to create both types of teeth in a piece of metal, it’s an expensive part that’s usually specific to a single gearbox. Proper miter gears are precise matching sets defined by factors like face width, diameter, tooth count, and axis angles.

posts.name: Bailey
posts.cooked:
I don’t follow VEX, is differential swerve common. This very much appears to be a differential swerve module using “crown gears”. Not really- My hands are actually the ones in that picture. Foster is cross-posting a question he asked on VEX Forum.  

I had posted about a VEX IQ replica of FIRST Robotics Competition 148’s 2023 robot, and it uses some custom differential swerve modules, that a former fellow VEX employee and 148 mentor & I worked on for a bit about 2 years ago. Foster wanted to see more, so I posted a breakdown of the modules, and sent a video of this module, which was a different revision, as it demonstrates the differential part of the mechanism a bit easier. The Spur/Crown compound gears intrigued him, but TBH I didn’t know if they had a special name.  

Unfortunately, the robot is still incomplete. I need to get around to finishing the intake one of these days. Everything else works, though – Differential swerve, 2-Stage Cascading Elevator, Elevator Pivot/Rotation, Power is sent up the robot to the intake motor, it just doesn’t have anything to spin yet.  

Some pictures:  
[Image descriptions and links removed due to instruction constraints]  

This second picture is the module on the robot. Picture Foster sent is of a different module that packages differently, but is a bit easier to understand.  

Thread for reference: [Link removed due to instruction constraints]

posts.name: Bailey
posts.cooked:
The text is:
The gears are versatile, acting as bevel or spur gears, but they're not suitable for heavy loads or efficiency.

These gears were common in HEXBUGs.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: A contrate gear is one where the teeth are on the face but it meshes with a normal spur gear. There is a pitch plane instead of conical pitch surfaces seen in a bevel gear. Here’s a good picture: And more looking crown gear is another term for this.
Weldingrod1: And more looking... crown gear is the other word for this. All roads lead to crown gear

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: Ah, yes, the design! (At least that’s where I remember seeing it first). Or at least very close to the power paths. Your daily dose of ridiculousness - 775 pro differential swerve. I drew this up on the weekend to see if I could. I was inspired by the awesome swerve posted here: pic: Swerve Module, 2910 MK1 - CD-Media: Photos - Chief Delphi. And I remembered the differential swerve idea posted here: Pic: 4143 differential swerve concept - CD-Media: Photos - Chief Delphi. My goal was to come up with a compact swerve module, run by two 775 pros, which handled both power and steering (via differential speed). Here’s the (incomplete) result.

link_counts.title: Your daily dose of ridiculousness - 775 pro differential swerve

posts.name: Foster
posts.cooked: Thanks @Skyehawk for digging into the 2017s to pull out the @nuclearnerd design. Back in the day, I was part of Team 1640 Sab-bot-age and we loved swerves. So I've been into swerve designs ever since. On the VEX path, I've built several V5 robots and one VEXIQ. VEXIQ is a big deal and I was super stoked when @bkahl shared some pics of his VEXIQ swerve bot. It looks similar to Brendan’s design. They fixed the drive-to-Steve ratio problem using bevel gears and tiny wheels. Then there's this video I linked showing the build. The white gears were 3D printed—it’s cool how they hacked the concept. But the naming is tricky because roboteers rename everything, so screws become twisty holders. I’m not sure if anyone knows the right term for those white gears. Maybe CD crew can help? I think the name could be "crowned spur gears." They’re supposed to have a crown or outward curve to assist meshing. But I need confirmation before jumping in.

link_counts.title: 02-96200P2 Crowned Gear With Pinion - OWI Inc. dba: Robotikits™ Direct

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: VEX in Delmarva - Chief Roboteer STEMRobotics

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Crowing of gear teeth adds a slight bulge to the tooth face, ensuring the contact patch remains away from the edges even with minor misalignment. This serves as a useful tool to reduce stress concentration.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: A pinion is a small gear that meshes with a larger gear or a rack, functioning as the driver. spur gears are standard straight-cut gears designed for meshing with similar gears, typically along specific rotational axes. they are simple, easy to manufacture, making them the most common type. despite advances in technology like 3d printing and 4-axis milling, spur gears remain essential due to their simplicity and widespread use.
